Contact Me

Software Engineer

I started my journey as a Software Engineer in 2005, learning to build my own video games in Flash and Visual Basic 6, 15 years later, I've worked with over 100 companies, built countless custom web applications, and developed an eclectic toolbelt in the process. I'm a jack-of-all-trades who has directly contributed to every aspect of software development; from sales to architecture. My bread-and-butter is database design and server-side programming.

Today I run my own consulting company, Esper Innovations.

Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.

— Martin Fowler

Teacher

Teaching has always been a passion of mine, I caught the teaching bug when I took on a Teacher's Assistant role in my high school programming class; I've always felt at home educating my peers and coworkers. As an Undergraduate Fellow at Plymouth State I developed assignments and curriculum with my professors and mentored my peers.

Nowadays I teach an intense 6-month web programming bootcamp for UNH. I'm working with my second group of students.

You have to be confident in yourself and your own ability, before you are willing to help another.

— Simon Sinek

Hobbyist

I consider myself a lifelong learner — at any point in time you'll find me deep in the midst of at least one new hobby. Brewing beer, painting, balloon twisting, model making, ukulele, woodworking, cocktails, astronomy, are just a few I've dove into. I'm captivated by pulling the curtain back on a community unfamiliar to me, learning their methodologies and making something new.

Recently I've been teaching myself how to sew.

The broadness of my interests gives me an excellent perspective to do what I do, and I wouldn't have it any other way.

— Adam Savage
